clusters.name: Staten Island Housing
clusters.action: Review and prioritize these housing-related suggestions

nodes.summary: Accessory dwelling units (ADUs) are a proven way to create housing & help homeowners. Homeowners filing to build them across boroughs including Staten Island.
Highlighting past high permitting in Manhattan (13,000 units in 1960 vs low in 1990s) to argue for less restrictive regulations to allow more housing.
Propose 150k homes in Bronx, 100k in Manhattan (infill + conversions), 250k in Staten Island/South Brooklyn with beauty, density, and green space.
Build a subway tunnel to Staten Island for 7-10 min trips and enable much more housing on the island.
Apply Tokyo-style zoning to Staten Island as experiment, use tax revenue to extend subway lines to the island.
Criticizes council members for proposing housing on inconvenient islands while their districts build none; calls for housing in existing neighborhoods.
Build affordable housing first on helipads ruining enjoyment of Governor’s Island (satirical support for more housing there).
Build dense, affordable city-run 5+ story housing complexes (not for-profit).
Set minimum sidewalk width of 8 feet tied to zoning; fund widening program for substandard sidewalks.
Dense, walkable neighborhoods connected by extensive passenger rail to solve urban issues.

clusters.name: Pedestrian Infrastructure
clusters.action: Review and prioritize these sidewalks-related suggestions

nodes.summary: Narrow streets, widen sidewalks, extend property lines into streets for more space/revenue.
Make sidewalks bigger and better (double-loaded sidewalks).
Implement “school streets” (car-free blocks beside schools during drop-off/pick-up) for safety and enjoyment.
Implement “school streets” (car-free blocks beside schools).
Urbanize with connecting sidewalks, updated crosswalks, mid/small intersections.
Fantastic opportunity for human-focused street redesign: wide sidewalks, trees, outdoor dining, benches.
Focus on safety (more officers, stop panhandling), expand outdoor dining/leisure, streetscape improvements, public investments over subsidies.
Support walkable urban neighborhoods with social interest, public conveniences, street-level retail.

clusters.name: Green Infrastructure
clusters.summary: 2 citizens advocating for green space improvements
clusters.action: Review and prioritize these green space-related suggestions

nodes.summary: Increase permeable infrastructure/replace car space with green space in flood-prone areas for resilience.
Reinstated city plan for southern McGuinness Boulevard in Greenpoint

clusters.name: Bus Lane Expansion
clusters.action: Review and prioritize these transit-related suggestions

nodes.summary: More buses/routes, turn dead malls into community centers/art spaces/indoor plazas, foot/cycle paths to parks/transit.
Incident highlights dangers in protected bike lanes near stopped school buses where children are active; calls for registration

Protected bike lane proposal on Brooklyn and Kingston Avenues in East Flatbush (Community Board 9) deemed essential due to 10 schools within one block; project establishes first protected bike connections in area lacking such infrastructure.
Construction underway for 1.5-mile parking-protected bike lane on Bedford Avenue in Bed-Stuy
NYC DOT school safety project proposes two-way protected bike lane on 7th Avenue between 86th Street and Poly Place in southern Brooklyn (CB 10)
nodes.link: focusing on improved crossings and separation for students commuting by bike.

nodes.summary: Completed protected bike lane on Court Street in Brooklyn (near downtown schools) reduces car speeds
Ongoing litigation challenges NYC DOT protected bike lane on Court Street in Brooklyn
nodes.link: strengthened by Queens precedent requiring removal of 31st Street bike lane

nodes.summary: Radio discussion on proposal to remove existing protected bike lane in unspecified Brooklyn location
Brooklyn judge halts NYC DOT's plan to tear up three blocks of protected bike lane on Bedford Avenue in Williamsburg
nodes.link: preserving the infrastructure amid community and safety concerns near residential areas including schools.

nodes.summary: Repurpose space near subway stations with wider sidewalks, larger bus shelters, bike parking, benches, micro forests, public restrooms.
United Jewish Organizations statement criticizes NYC DOT's redesigned protected bike lane on Bedford Avenue in Williamsburg and North Brooklyn for failing to address pedestrian safety risks
nodes.link: particularly for school children crossing the street.

nodes.summary: N-S bus lanes, expanded elevated bike lanes, priority signaling (context applied to NYC-style improvements).
More cops/tickets, red light/speed cameras, build pedestrian/bike infrastructure and sidewalks, narrow street lanes.
100 miles bus lanes in two years, subsidize e-bikes, expand sidewalks, install public sidewalk seating/bathrooms.
Pedestrianize 5th Ave with trees/gardens, light rail on 6th Ave, vibrant vendors/food/arts/music.

clusters.name: Public Safety
clusters.action: Review and prioritize these safety-related suggestions

nodes.summary: Parking/delivery reform, automated enforcement, congestion pricing, close sections to traffic; reduce driving by set percentage.
